channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Panel Cites ‘Terror’ Campaign Against Syrian Civilians
item.description: The Syrian government has orchestrated a policy of forced disappearances that amounts to a crime against humanity, United Nations investigators said in a report released on Thursday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Letter From Europe: Drawn Into the Tangle of Syria’s War
item.description: The deaths of two Britons shows how the Syrian war has drawn outsiders into its maw only to destroy them, as the region has done on many previous occasions.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Britain to Evacuate Its Citizens From South Sudan
item.description: Britain said on Thursday that it had dispatched an airplane to evacuate British nationals as clashes were reported to have spread in South Sudan following claims of an attempted coup.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: U.S. Prosecutor Defends Charges Against Indian Diplomat
item.description: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, offered a robust defense of the decision to arrest the diplomat, Devyani Khobragade, while India’s foreign minister on Thursday called for the case to be dropped.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Tokyo’s Governor Resigns Amid Scandal
item.description: Naoki Inose had admitted to receiving a half-million dollars during an election but said that it was a personal loan.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Putin Says Deal With Ukraine Was a Good-Will Gesture
item.description: The $15 billion loan and gas agreement threw a lifeline to Ukraine’s president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, who has been facing more than three weeks of civil unrest.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia traditionally holds a large news conference in December.

item.title: South Korean Cyberwarfare Unit Accused of Political Meddling
item.description: Military investigators asked prosecutors to indict 11 officials on charges of violating a law that bans public servants from meddling in politics.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Ambassador Visits Central African Republic Amid Bloodshed
item.description: The American ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, landed in the besieged capital of the Central African Republic on Thursday with a message: The United States is watching.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A woman and child walked through a refugee camp in the northwestern town of Bossangoa on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Bitcoin Investors Fret as Value of Virtual Currency Plunges
item.description: The virtual currency Bitcoin has taken a sharp tumble in value since Chinese regulators moved to restrict its usage.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: New curbs on the use of Bitcoins have contributed to a sell-off.

item.title: India Ink: The Ties that Bind Transgendered Communities
item.description: Ostracized by Indian society, hijras, or men who identify themselves as women, find ways to form their own families.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI

item.title: European Officials Agree on Plan for Failed Banks
item.description: Finance ministers announced Wednesday that they had made significant progress on how to structure a rescue fund for failing banks, though they offered no details.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Jeroen Dijsselbloem, left, the Dutch finance minister and head of the euro zone finance ministers, expressed optimism Wednesday that a deal was near.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Coal Baron Tumbles into Debt
item.description: Last year a Shanxi coal baron, Xing Libin, spent 70 million renminbi on his daughter’s wedding with jet aircraft for guests, Ferraris and pop stars, Chinese media reported. Now he’s 30 billion renminbi in debt, the government says.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A worker levels the coal on a freight train in Taiyuan in northern China's Shanxi province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Obama’s Choice for China Envoy a Longtime Free Trade Advocate
item.description: Senator Max Baucus, President Obama’s pick as United States envoy to China, has deep experience in working on United States-China trade issues.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Sen. Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, appears well equipped to deal with the ability of American businesses to operate in an increasingly complex Chinese environment.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Barred From College Entrance Exams, in a Blow for China’s Blind
item.description: Li Jinsheng, who is blind, wanted to take the national college entrance examinations to study at university. But the registration deadline passed without the authorities permitting him to do so.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chinese security guards checking the identity of students entering a school to take the national college entrance examinations in Beijing.

item.title: U.S. Prosecutor Defends Arrest of Indian Diplomat
item.description: Preet Bharara, the federal prosecutor in Manhattan, said the charges were warranted and that the diplomat had been accorded unusual courtesy.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade, the deputy consul general in New York. Her arrest on charges of visa fraud has enraged Indian officials.

item.title: Bolivia Accuses U.S. of Aiding in an American’s Escape
item.description: An American facing money-laundering charges who escaped house arrest and crossed into Peru had the help of American officials, Bolivian officials say.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: State Dept. Warns of New Terrorist Group Posing Threat to U.S. Interests in Africa
item.description: The State Department warned that a new terrorist group linked to an Algerian militant has emerged as “the greatest near-term threat” to Western interests in Africa.
item.category: Mujao (Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: After Bangladesh Factory Collapse, Bleak Struggle for Survivors
item.description: Eight months after more than 1,100 Bangladeshi workers died and many were injured in the Rana Plaza disaster, survivors and families are left with no guarantees of help or compensation.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey Jailing the Most Journalists
item.description: For the second consecutive year, Turkey is imprisoning more journalists than any other country, according to a report from the Committee to Protect Journalists released Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By HANNAH C. MURPHY

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria Confirms British Surgeon Died in Prison, but Calls it Suicide
item.description: With the confirmation that a British surgeon in a Syrian prison had died, his family on accused British authorities of failing to protect him.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Anticorruption Bill Passes
item.description: India’s Parliament gave final approval on Wednesday to a bill creating an independent anticorruption agency, after more than four decades of debate over how to curb graft.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: More Shiite Pilgrims Killed
item.description: Shiites making pilgrimages in Iraq were targeted on Wednesday by gunmen and suicide bombers, medical and police officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Madrid Journal: Spreading Spain’s Glory in Thin, Slow Slices
item.description: Florencio Sanchidrián, who says he considers himself an ambassador for Spain’s famed Ibérico ham, travels the world slicing meat, with flair, for V.I.P.’s.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Gianfranco Tripodo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Florencio Sanchidrián giving a class on cutting Ibérico ham at a hostelry school in Madrid.

item.title: Günther Förg, Prolific German Artist, Dies at 61
item.description: Mr. Förg was a painter, sculptor and photographer whose work exemplified, toyed with, tweaked and commented on modernism.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER

item.title: Eyad El-Sarraj, Psychiatrist Who Fought for Rights of Palestinians, Is Dead at 70
item.description: Dr. Sarraj pioneered mental health care in Gaza and became an internationally recognized human rights advocate, criticizing both the Israeli and Palestinian authorities.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Eyad El-Sarraj, who championed nonviolence, in 2011. Recently he had promoted reconciliation between Fatah and Hamas.
